ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about fairly new techniques for doing fMRI analysis, and how different data science methods are being applied in neuroscience research
I learned the workflow of computational neuroscience methods and applied them to real human fMRI data.

definitely one of the most useful courses ive taken at yale. dont underestimate how much python youll need to know though (theres not much support offered in terms of coding, which wouldve been useful).
I learned a lot about current fmri analyses with modern machine learning methods
A host of machine learning and neuroimaging analysis techniques, debugging/critical thinking skills, and enhanced passion for neuroscience!
So much. First, more Python skills. Second, how to read and interpret fMRI data, and apply various statistical techniques to examine it. Third, how to more closely read a scientific paper.

We learned a lot in this class. We learned a lot of the preprocessing, ML, and analyzing techniques used to in imaging practice. Some specific topics were use of classifiers, shared response modeling, region of interest correlations, connectivity and more!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was nice in that there was both a lecture component in which we were able to learn about the background and uses for the techniques, and also a more practical component in which we were coding and applying the techniques ourselves. It was also nice that the course facilitated student discussion and collaboration on psets.
This class was very informative and fun! I don't see anything that wrong with it.

breakout rooms didnt really foster much collaboration, i think this course is probably a lot more doable in an in-person setting. final project was cool, and had a lot of options to work with different datasets.

The lecture was very engaging, and I really appreciated the fact that the professor paused at each step to make sure everyone understood the material. As a minor weakness, the notebook sometimes contained error or misinstruction.

Strengths: engaging lectures, fair homework assignments, useful material, fantastic TFs
Weaknesses: only having 1 day to do the homework - Wednesdays tend to be the busiest day of the week for most students (I for example had 4 lectures on Wednesdays) so even just 1 more day to do the homework every week (which would also make sense since students likely won't be as busy on Thursdays if they're taking a 3hr Tuesday lab) would have alleviated a lot of stress. I basically couldn't do anything other than this class on Wednesdays after my lectures, which wasn't always fair to the other courses I had quizzes/tests in on Wednesdays. It's also kind of hard to really remember the material from prior weeks when the whole course is crammed into less than a day and a half of each week. I understand the sentiment of not wanting students to spend a long time on the assignments, but I think 2 days to do the homework instead of just 1 would be a lot more fair. Otherwise, great course though.

Incredibly well organized, clear + constructive feedback. Grading scheme was clear from the start. Turk-Browne and Tristan (TA) were both incredibly responsive, accommodating, and overwhelmingly wonderful. Best class I've taken at Yale!

Perhaps it can be improved with posting the solutions of the notebook after its due? It can be helpful to look at another of doing things, especially when just starting out and when youre trying to learn how to gain better coding practices.

The weekly notebook due the next day after class was very helpful. I think I did most of my learning for this class while working on this project. While it is a very quick turnaround, it is enough time to work on it if you budget well. They were very rewarding!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course adapted pretty well to an online format, especially since much of the more practical parts were computer-based. Breakout rooms helped with more individualized conversations with other groups of students.
Of course the online format is always a challenge and can't replace face to face interactions. But the discussion based virtual lectures and hackathons on Zoom were really great!

I think this course did quite well in terms of the pandemic. There was thorough class engagement, though I thought at times the lectures might have been better to be split a bit more and require more activities.

I think the setup for this class worked well virtually. The breakout rooms were used for the activity portion of the class, and that allowed us to work in small groups. I think this was well organized

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This course was a pretty deep dive into fMRI-related analysis techniques, and provides a solid foundation for thinking about why and how researchers address problems and questions they're interested in. It also introduced us to various recent papers and research using the methods we learned, which was cool.
I would recommend this course to those who are interested in human neuroscience research because it gives you an in-depth walkthrough of how it's done as well as hands on experience with the process.

yes take it if you want to learn cutting edge techniques in fmri analysis. like its actually so relevant and really cool. but dont expect much help with python (unless you have a TA as great as Tristan) so be prepared to take a little longer on psets if youre not as familiar with coding. really fast turnaround on psets so youll be busy on the day of and after class but then its not bad the other days. linear might also be helpful in better understanding some of the methods.
If you're interested in computational neuroscience, this course is definitely worth it, but otherwise, the work may just feel too much.
Yes, I definitely would - the skills you learn in it are really useful and Professor Turk-Browne's a great lecturer.
More than any other course at Yale.
Yes, especially if youre a neuroscience major, these tools will be invaluable.

Yes! I felt like I had learned so much about how to analyze and process fMRI images by the end of this class! If you are programming oriented and think youd be working with neuroimaging, I think this is a must take!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live Lectures
virtual lab, virtual lecture, and virtual seminar
virtual lecture/seminar + virtual lab
Lecture, paper presentations, notebooks / office hours
